concepts.name: Logic
concepts.definition: Logic is the study of the methods and principles of reasoning

concepts.name: Argument
concepts.definition: An argument uses a set of facts or assumptions, called premises, to support a conclusion

concepts.name: Fallacy
concepts.definition: A fallacy is a deceptive argumentâ€”an argument in which the conclusion is not well supported by the premises

concepts.name: Proposition
concepts.definition: Propositions are statements that make (propose) a claim that may be either true or false. A proposition must have the structure of a complete sentence and must make a distinct assertion or denial.
concepts.example: '7 + 9 = 2' is a proposition, even though false. 'Are you going?' is NOT a proposition.

concepts.name: Negation
concepts.definition: The opposite of a proposition is called its negation. Negations are also propositions because they have complete sentence structure and may be true or false.
concepts.example: Negation of 'Joan is sitting' is 'Joan is not sitting'

concepts.name: And Statements (Conjunctions)
concepts.definition: An 'and' statement is called a conjunction. The conjunction p and q is true only if p and q are both true.
concepts.example: 'Hard test AND got A' is true only if both are true

concepts.name: Or Statements (Disjunctions)
concepts.definition: A compound statement made with 'or' is called a disjunction. We assume inclusive 'or' - true if either/both propositions are true.
concepts.example: Inclusive: 'illness or injury' covers both. Exclusive: 'soup or salad' means one choice.

concepts.name: If...Then Statements
concepts.definition: Conditional propositions propose something true (then part) on condition something else is true (if part).
